Primordial Elements

The primordial elements of creation are Atman, Mana, and Anicca. These are further divided into the plentiful and the scarce.

Anicca

Anicca, also called 'grey matter', is the fundamental physical matter of all, and the only infinite primordial element. In its default state it is a colourless immaterial, and it can maintain no form without the exertion of divine will represented by mana.

Mana

Mana, also known as 'time', or 'permanence', is the will of an individual atman. Mana is naturally generated by all atman in differing quantities, but always enough to sustain their own existence. An atman which ceases to generate enough mana to sustain its own existence becomes a hunger, which is fundamentally different. An atman which has no mana ceases to, or does not, exist.

Atman are capable of applying mana to manipulate the form of anicca. An instant of mana allows a mote of anicca to maintain a form other than its default for just that instant, after which it reverts. Anicca imbued with a larger quantity of mana enters into linear time, gradually depleting this resevoir of mana until it finally revents to its default form. In this way, anicca, and thereby entire creations, or trinities, are able retain a form even while unattended by an atman.

Atman

Atman are commonly known as souls. They are the nature of intelligent entities separated from the physical form of anicca, and capable of manipulating the other primordial elements. Atman are further divided into divine and mortal, and hunger, and may move between these divisions by means of Soul Enrichment. They may also be joined, split, or even destroyed outright through force of will, or by the exploitation of certain physical structures, similarly to how a vessel traps a soul.

Roles of Atman

Each category and caste of atman plays an important role in the nature of Creations, and the Balance of True Creation.

Categories of Atman

Divine

Divine, or 'immortal', atman include Gods, Watchers and Soul Stewards. The classification requires only that they produce mana more quickly than it would be consumed by the vessel required to trap them, but most far surpass this requirement. They are innately capable of manipulating atman, and due to their relative abundance of mana, may exert control over anicca which is effectively indominable by mortal atman.

Mortal

Mortal atman are those which produce mana more slowly that the vessel required to them, though most fall far below this mark. They are not innately capable of manipulating other atman or large quantities of mana, though they may do so according to the laws of a Creation (see arcane magic).

Hunger

A Hunger is any atman which produces less mana than it requires to sustain its own existance. They are neither divine nor mortal because the rate of mana consumption by a vessel sufficient to trap them, as well as their capacity for manipulating mana and atman, is directly proportional to their current resevoir of mana. Hunger are usually malicous and seek to sustain their own existance by feeding upon the mana resevoirs of other atman.

Trinity

Anicca imbued with mana may be formed into a vessel suitable to trap an atman. The quantity of anicca and mana required to form a vessel suitable to trap an atman differs greatly, and the mana requirement includes, but is not limited to that required to sustain the form of the anicca. Such a vessel retaining an atman forms a trinity otherwise known as life, from which it is not trivial to separate any element even if the retained atman is mortal and the agent of separation is immortal. The mana, or will, that the trinity is imbued with is given to the restrained atman to use to control the anicca, or even other anicca surrounding it (see arcane magic). The most effective way to break the trinity of life is to sufficiently damage either the anicca or mana it is composed of (collectively named the 'vessel'), such that it can no longer restrain the atman.

While the atman may be enriched or marred by such an experience, memories collated are encrypted in some fashion which means that they may be beyond recovery without some sample of the original vessel by which they were generated.

Girdles are an exceptional example of such vessels, trapping many atman, and vast reservoir of mana which is not bound to any particular anicca.
